timeline.author: 2xsaiko
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -93,7 +107,7 @@ CLASS net/minecraft/class_918 net/minecraft/client/render/item/ItemRenderer
 		ARG 2 stack
 		ARG 3 x
 		ARG 4 y
-	METHOD method_4026 renderGuiItem (Lnet/minecraft/class_1309;Lnet/minecraft/class_1799;II)V
+	METHOD method_4026 renderGuiItemInner (Lnet/minecraft/class_1309;Lnet/minecraft/class_1799;II)V

replies.bodyText: It follows the naming convention of blitInner (from 1.15.2). It's a private implementation method for renderGuiItem. The public one with the same signature (method_27951) just passes through to this method without doing anything extra, as do all the overloads.
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: doRenderInScreen innerRenderInScreen sounds better. We tend ton use screen over gui and just call it in gui/screen than gui/screen item imo
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: screen is just a type of GUI that... well... takes up your whole screen
replies.author: Prospector

timeline.bodyText: would recommend this to be renderGuiItem and the player one with renderGuiItemWithPlayer
timeline.author: shedaniel
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -54,6 +54,19 @@ CLASS net/minecraft/class_918 net/minecraft/client/render/item/ItemRenderer ARG 4 overlay ARG 5 matrices ARG 6 vertices + METHOD method_27951 renderInGui (Lnet/minecraft/class_1309;Lnet/minecraft/class_1799;II)V + COMMENT Renders an item in a GUI with an attached entity. + COMMENT + COMMENT

The entity is used to calculate model overrides for the item. + ARG 1 entity + ARG 2 stack + ARG 3 x + ARG 4 y + METHOD method_27953 renderInGuiWithoutEntity (Lnet/minecraft/class_1799;II)V

replies.bodyText:
or I meant renderItemInGuiWithPlayer, depends which one you prefer.
imo this is because calling with player is a "special case" for it, and calling without an entity is not
replies.author: shedaniel

replies.bodyText: I feel like the player one is the default one that should be used in GUIs, since for example HandledScreen does that.
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: HandledScreen is player specific then I guess, I don't feel like we should attach the player without the withPlayer thing at least, the player can be null, which makes this the same as no entity. So let the modder know by adding the withPlayer thing
replies.author: shedaniel

replies.bodyText: I can run a usage search in Enigma and see which one Mojang considers the "default" one (by number of usages).
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText:
With the player:

Without an entity:

With a manually specified entity (which is the client player in all cases):
replies.author: Juuxel

replies.bodyText: Does the renderer apply model overrides with the player given, or what is the player used for?
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText:
It is for the overrides predicate, for example, the one for lefthanded, I would say that the player one is mainly for handled screens because it is to detect properties for the player, so it would be essential to add WithPlayer at the end to inform the modder that it will use the player.
For things like the advancement tabs, they are not player dependent, you don't want to see the icon change due to the player doing some weird things.
replies.author: shedaniel

replies.bodyText: then WithOverrides suffix is better than WithPlayer suffix.
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: Is this distinction necessary? Can they both not just be renderInGui? The arguments and documentation can describe other behaviours.
replies.author: ChloeDawn

replies.bodyText: this is, as this method does not allow item model's overrides to be checked or applied.
replies.author: liach

replies.bodyText: @ChloeDawn There are conflicting signatures (ItemStack, int, int) with two of them (the player one and the no-entity one), so they have to have different names.
replies.author: Juuxel
